data.title: Uninsured Americans on the rise, as 27 million don't have healthcare
data.meta_description: According to the CDC, the number of Americans without health insurance has gone up so far in 2024, breaking a streak of record low-figures.
data.text:
The said the number of Americans without health insurance has gone up so far in 2024, breaking a streak of record low-figures.

Dr. Richard Ricciardi isn't just an associate dean in the School of Nursing at George Washington University; he also practices at a clinic in Maryland for people who don't have health insurance. The patients he sees are a part of the 8% of Americans without health insurance.

It's a number that represents more than 27 million people.

We do the best we can with the limited resources we have as a community-based clinic to accept individuals who don't have health insurance," Ricciardi said.

As for why more Americans don't have health insurance, Ricciardi said there are likely a few reasons, including access to Medicaid.

You know, in many states, the rules surrounding who is eligible to receive Medicaid has changed," said Ricciardi.

Jacqueline Epstein, a professor of practice in general legal studies, said not only did access to Medicaid change this year, but so did the cost.

Medicaid part 'A' and part 'B' -- the premiums and deductibles increased in 2024," Epstein said.

Plus, Epstein said the economy and inflation could also be contributing factors.

Increased inflation and cost of living -- they're having an effect on what people are willing to spend their monthly budget on and health insurance. The premiums have risen," said Epstein.

Epstein also said urgent care could be a contributing factor into the uninsured numbers. According to , at least 26% of adults visited an urgent care in the last year.
